importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The Ostwall complex was abandoned by the Nazis in 1945, marking the end of its military use and the beginning of its postwar history.
The London Tunnels are expected to open as a public tourist attraction in 2028, following a $149 million transformation project.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Ostwall was constructed during the 1930s and abandoned by the Nazis in 1945, reflecting a period of intense military expansion and wartime planning.
The London Tunnels are currently undergoing renovation and are scheduled to open to the public in 2028, signaling a modern interest in Cold War history and underground infrastructure.

keyTakeAways: The Ostwall in Poland was built by the Nazis as a fortified underground city for soldiers and combat operations, later abandoned and repurposed as a dark tourism site.
The Passage of Commodus in Rome is a 2,000-year-old tunnel linked to an assassination attempt on Emperor Commodus, adding historical intrigue to its public opening.
The London Tunnels, originally built for WWII shelter, are now being transformed into a major tourist attraction, inspired by the real-life origins of James Bond’s Q Branch.
Kayaköy, Turkey, is a ghost town abandoned after the Greco-Turkish war, now a haunting example of post-conflict urban decay.
Babylon, Iraq, remains a historically significant ruin, now under threat due to overgrowth and poor maintenance, yet still evokes a sense of ancient power and grandeur.
The Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum in West Virginia, once a place of medical compassion, is now a haunted tourist site that blends history with paranormal storytelling.

namedEntities.name: Ostwall
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Nazi-built underground complex in Poland, 20 miles long, containing tunnels, shafts, and combat facilities.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Ostwall is the central focus of the article, serving as a key example of Nazi military infrastructure beneath the surface of a peaceful Polish village.

namedEntities.name: Pniewo
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A small Polish village where the Ostwall is located.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The village provides geographical context for the Ostwall, highlighting how a seemingly quiet rural area hides a vast underground complex.

namedEntities.name: Poland
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country in Central Europe where the Ostwall is situated.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The location of the Ostwall in Poland reflects Nazi expansion and military planning in Eastern Europe during World War II.

namedEntities.name: Bunker People
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A subculture in the 1980s and 1990s that occupied the Ostwall tunnels, hosting dangerous events such as raves and weddings.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Bunker People show how abandoned military sites were repurposed for social and cultural activities, influencing the site's transformation into a modern tourist destination.

namedEntities.name: Międzyrzecz Fortified Region Museum
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A museum that now manages 19 miles of the Ostwall tunnels for public exploration.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This institution is central to the modern tourism development of the Ostwall, making it accessible and educational to the public.

namedEntities.name: Passage of Commodus
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 1,800-foot Roman tunnel near the Colosseum used by Emperor Commodus to avoid assassination.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This tunnel adds historical depth to the article by connecting ancient Roman history with real-life political intrigue and survival.

namedEntities.name: Emperor Commodus
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Roman emperor known for his cruelty and who allegedly survived an assassination attempt in the Passage of Commodus.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Commodus is relevant due to his historical association with the tunnel, and his portrayal in pop culture (e.g. Joaquin Phoenix in 'Gladiator') adds cultural relevance.

namedEntities.name: London Tunnels
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A mile-long series of underground chambers built during WWII for civilian shelter, later used by the Special Operations Executive (SOE).
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The London Tunnels are a key example of Cold War-era infrastructure and are being transformed into a major tourist attraction.

namedEntities.name: Special Operations Executive (SOE)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A British intelligence agency during WWII, considered the real-life inspiration for James Bond’s Q Branch.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The SOE’s historical connection to the London Tunnels links them to espionage and the origin of modern spy fiction.

namedEntities.name: Kayaköy
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A town in southwest Turkey that was abandoned over a century ago after the Greco-Turkish war.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kayaköy is a physical reminder of war-induced displacement and urban abandonment, serving as a haunting example of post-war decay.

namedEntities.name: Babylon
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An ancient Mesopotamian city in modern-day Iraq, once one of the most important historical cities in antiquity.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Babylon represents ancient civilization and is now in decline due to environmental and maintenance issues, symbolizing historical fragility.

namedEntities.name: Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A former psychiatric facility in West Virginia known for its overcrowding and historical connection to mental health treatment.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The asylum is presented as a modern haunted tourist attraction, blending history with paranormal themes.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A CNN article explores various underground and historically significant sites around the world, including the Nazi-built Ostwall tunnel complex in Poland, the Roman tunnel where Emperor Commodus may have survived an assassination attempt, the London Tunnels used during WWII and now being redeveloped into a tourist site, abandoned towns like Kayaköy in Turkey, and the ancient ruins of Babylon in Iraq. It also highlights the Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum in West Virginia as a haunted tourist attraction, emphasizing how historical trauma, war, and forgotten infrastructure have been repurposed into modern tourism experiences. The article underscores the enduring human fascination with the hidden, the mysterious, and the past, showing how dangerous or forgotten places now serve as both educational and experiential destinations.
title: Deep underground, the Nazis built a city for thousands of soldiers. Now it’s a tourist attraction
